{{other uses|Marrakesh Treaty (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox treaty | name = Marrakesh VIP Treaty | long_name = Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works to Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities | image = | caption = [[Stevie Wonder]] addresses the Marrakesh Diplomatic Conference on 28 June 2013. | type = Multilateral | date_drafted = | date_signed = {{Start date|2013|6|28|df=yes}} | location_signed = [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]] | date_sealed = | date_effective = {{Start date|2016|9|30|df=yes}} | condition_effective = Ratification of 20 states | negotiators = | signatories = 80<ref name="WIPO-Administered Treaties">{{cite web|title=WIPO-Administered Treaties|url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ShowResults.jsp?lang=en&treaty_id=843|accessdate=25 July 2018}}</ref> | parties = 47 (74 countries including EUs 28 member states) | ratifiers = | depositor = [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] | language = | languages = | wikisource = | image_width = | date_expiration = }}
The '''Marrakesh VIP Treaty''' (formally the '''Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities''', colloquially '''MVT'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Summary of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works for Persons Who Are Blind, Visually Impaired, or Otherwise Print Disabled|url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ip/marrakesh/summary_marrakesh.html|publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]]|accessdate=31 May 2016}}</ref>) is a [[multilateral treaty|treaty]] on [[copyright]] adopted in [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]], on 28 June 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wipo.int/dc2013/en/ |title=Diplomatic Conference to Conclude a Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works by Visually Impaired Persons and Persons with Print Disabilities |publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]] |date=28 June 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21582039-blind-people-defeat-lobbyists-tussle-about-copyright-between-lines |title=Between the lines: Blind people defeat lobbyists in a tussle about copyright |work=[[The Economist]] |date=20 July 2013 }}</ref>
== Treaty == The treaty allows for copyright exceptions to facilitate the creation of accessible versions of books and other copyrighted works for visually impaired persons. It sets a norm for countries ratifying the treaty to have a domestic copyright exception covering these activities, and allowing for the import and export of such materials.
Sixty three (recently 28 European countries also ratified) countries signed the treaty as of the close of the diplomatic conference in Marrakesh. The ratification of 20 states was required for the treaty to enter into effect;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wipo.int/pressroom/en/articles/2013/article_0018.html |title=Stevie Wonder hails landmark WIPO treaty boosting access to books for blind and visually impaired persons |publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]] |date=28 June 2013 }}</ref> the 20th ratification was received on 30 June 2016, and the treaty entered into force on 30 September 2016.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.wipo.int/pressroom/en/articles/2016/article_0007.html |title="Canada’s Accession to Marrakesh Treaty Brings Treaty into Force|date=June 30, 2016|publisher=WIPO Press Release}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.davidhammerstein.com/2016/09/marrakesh-treaty-day-1.html|title=Marrakesh Treaty: Day 1|author=David Hammerstein|access-date=18 January 2017}}</ref>
=== Ratification === India was the first country to ratify the treaty, <ref>http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/notifications/marrakesh/treaty_marrakesh_1.html</ref> <ref>http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/india-ratifies-marrakesh-treaty-for-visually-impaired/article6171554.ece</ref> on 24 July 2014. As of October 15, 2018<ref>http://www.wipo.int/export/sites/www/treaties/en/documents/pdf/marrakesh.pdf</ref>, 80 countries have signed the Treaty and 71 states have ratified it including EU:s 28 memberstates who ratified as one entety (notification number 45) <ref>http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/notifications/marrakesh/treaty_marrakesh_45.html</ref> ) <ref name="WIPO-Administered Treaties"/> , most recently Saudi Arabia <ref>https://twitter.com/WIPO/status/1065252208583823360</ref>.
In March 2015, the [[Council of the European Union]] accused the [[European Commission]] of delaying the adoption of the treaty by EU and called upon the Commission "to submit without delay the necessary legislative proposal".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tacd-ip.org/archives/1325 |title=Marrakesh in the EU: facing the excuses and delay tactics after Council statement |publisher=[[Trans Atlantic Consumer Dialogue|TransAtlantic Consumer Dialogue]] |work=IP Policy Committee blog |date=7 April 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statewatch.org/news/2015/apr/eu-council-marrakesh-treaty-guidance-7321-15.pdf |title=Proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works for Persons who are Blind, Visually Impaired, or Otherwise Print Disabled — Guidance for further work |publisher=[[Council of the European Union]] |format=PDF }}</ref> There is continued opposition by some EU member states.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.davidhammerstein.com/2017/01/germany-tries-to-cripple-right-to-read-eu-marrakesh-treaty-legislation-for-visually-impaired-persons-with-a-publishers-compensation|title=Germany moves against "right to read" Marrakesh Treaty for visually-impaired persons|author=David Hammerstein|access-date=18 January 2017}}</ref>
On September 20, 2017 the EU Commission published a directive and a regulation on the Marrakesh treaty that has to be transposed into national law, in all 28 member states, deadline for transposition: October 11, 2018.<ref>https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/news/implementation-marrakesh-treaty-eu-law</ref>
The [[European Union]] has committed to ratification and implementation of the Treaty, and member states are required to update their national laws to implement the Treaty's requirements later in 2018. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euroblind.org/campaigns-and-activities/current-campaigns/marrakesh-treaty |title=The Marrakesh Treaty|author=European Blind Union |access-date=31 July 2018 }}</ref>
The [[European Union]] ratified the treaty for all 28 members on October 1, 2018. The provisions of the Treaty will go into effect across the EU (including in the United Kingdom) on January 1, 2019. <ref>https://twitter.com/i/status/1046805138168598536</ref><ref>http://www.wipo.int/pressroom/en/articles/2018/article_0008.html</ref>
On June 28, 2018, the [[U.S. Senate]] approved it and the implementation bill {{USBill|115|s|2559}}<ref>https://www.congress.gov/search?searchResultViewType=expanded&q=%7B%22congress%22%3A%22115%22%2C%22source%22%3A%5B%22legislation%22%2C%22treaties%22%5D%2C%22search%22%3A%22Marrakesh+Treaty%22%7D</ref> without apparent opposition; the [[US House|House]] approved S.2559 via [[unanimous consent]] on September 25 2018. The bill and the Treaty were signed into law by the [[President of the United States|President]] on October 9, 2018. <ref>https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/president-donald-j-trump-signs-h-r-46-h-r-2259-h-r-4854-h-r-4958-s-791-s-1668-s-2559-law/</ref><ref>Alan K. Ota. [http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/one-vote-mcconnell-approves-bill-blind With Only One Vote, McConnell Approves Treaty for the Blind], ''[[Roll Call]]''. 29 June 2018</ref><ref>https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/2559/all-actions-without-amendments?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22S.+2559%22%5D%7D&r=1</ref>

Conceived by [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] and [[John F. Kennedy]], the 1961 '''McCloy–Zorin Accords''' between the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]] established a foundation or "roadmap" for all future negotiations and international treaties with regard to nuclear and general and complete disarmament under effective international control. Effectively aiming at abolishing war as an institution, it was unanimously passed by the [[UN General Assembly]] on 20 December.
The McCloy–Zorin Accords provided far-reaching measures. The Agreed Principles for General and Complete Disarmament, as they were also known, emphatically declared that war should "no longer [be] an instrument for settling international problems;" "general and complete disarmament" was to be "accompanied by the establishment of reliable procedures for the peaceful settlement of disputes." The agreement also called for the "dismantling of military establishments … cessation of the production of armaments … elimination of all stockpiles of [[Nuclear weapon|nuclear]], [[Chemical weapon|chemical]], [[Bacteriological weapon|bacteriological]] and other [[weapons of mass destruction]]s [and] … discontinuance of military expenditures." Member States were expected to make "agreed manpower" available to the United Nations, such as would be "necessary for an international peace force." In [[United Kingdom|Britain]] the trend was viewed with favor, its [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] apparently being happy "to see much in common between the Russian and the American plans," and aiming at "a master plan of our own, which would lead to the physical destruction of weapons, beginning now, and going on until the business is complete..."<ref>For an in-depth study see Andrew Martin, ''Legal Aspects of Disarmament,'' The British Institute of International and Comparative Law, London 1963 (An Address given under the auspices of The British Institute of International and Comparative Law on June 24, 1963, at the Royal Institute of International Affairs, Chatham House), p. 15 (International and Comparative Law Quarterly, Supplementary Publication No. 7, 1963)</ref> In 1963 Mr. [[Harold Wilson]], speaking for the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] in an address to the [[Fabian Society]] said that he would like to "establish a separate Ministry of Disarmament."<ref>Andrew Martin, ''Legal Aspects of Disarmament,'' The British Institute of International and Comparative Law, London 1963 (An Address given under the auspices of The British Institute of International and Comparative Law on June 24, 1963, at the Royal Institute of International Affairs, Chatham House), p. 14 (International and Comparative Law Quarterly, Supplementary Publication No. 7, 1963)</ref>

{{Orphan|date=November 2011}} {{COI|date=November 2017}} '''Revolo''' is a [[plug-in hybrid|plug-in]] [[Parallel hybrid|parallel]] [[Hybrid vehicle|hybrid]] technology that can be [[Retrofitting|retrofitted]] in both existing and new [[cars]]. This technology can also be used in buses and trucks. The technology was developed by [[KPIT Technologies]] and the product will be manufactured through a [[joint venture]] between [[Bharat Forge]] and KPIT. As part of the joint venture, KPIT will license the hybrid technology while Bharat Forge will provide manufacturing, assembly, and integration.
Pre-compliance tests conducted at the Automotive research Association of India (ARAI), [[Pune]] have confirmed that the technology provides [[fuel efficiency]] improvements by over 40 percent and reduction in [[green house gas]] (GHG) emissions by over 30%.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nasscom.in/Nasscom/templates/NormalPage.aspx?id=59416 |title = Bharat Forge And KPIT To Form A Joint Venture - Announce ‘New Hybrid Technology Solution’ for Automobiles |publisher = [[Nasscom]] |date = 2010-06-16 |accessdate = 2010-12-09}}</ref>
The technology is to be marketed to [[OEM]]s and individual vehicle owners through a network of dealerships.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.indianexpress.com/news/Bharat-Forge--KPIT-to-float-joint-venture/630376 |title = Bharat Forge, KPIT to float joint venture | publisher = [[Indian Express]] |date = 2010-06-07 |accessdate = 2010-12-09}}</ref>
==Background==
===Planning and concept=== The idea of Revolo first occurred to Tejas Kshatriya in 2008<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.livemint.com/2010/07/29211227/Cleaner-greener-cheaper.html |title = Cleaner, greener, cheaper | publisher = [[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]] |date = 2010-07-29 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref> when he was stuck in [[Mumbai]] traffic en route to [[Pune]].
KPIT sanctioned a team of four engineers for the project, which was kept separate from [[KPIT Cummins#Research and development|CREST]], the research and development center at KPIT. It took 2 years of research<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.thenational.ae/business/hybrid-car-makeover-to-hit-the-road |title = Hybrid car makeover to hit the road | publisher = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)]] |date = 2010-06-20 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref> and a budget under US$2 million<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.livemint.com/2010/07/29211227/Cleaner-greener-cheaper.html |title = Cleaner, greener, cheaper | publisher = [[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]] |date = 2010-07-29 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref> to evolve the idea through trial and error and several failures, including the inability of the system to withstand sudden surge in power when brakes were applied.
The research and development team studied the firing pattern of [[internal combustion engines]] and identified the weak spots that lead to fuel waste<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.thenational.ae/business/fill-the-gap-between-petrol-and-electric |title = Fill the gap between petrol and electric | publisher = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)]] |date = 2010-06-20 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref> and created a technology that can convert a passenger car to a hybrid that is environmentally friendly, cheap, fuel-efficient and at the same time offers good performance.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.thenational.ae/business/hybrid-car-makeover-to-hit-the-road |title = Hybrid car makeover to hit the road | publisher = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)]] |date = 2010-06-20 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>
Revolo is designed to work in typical stop-and-go city traffic and allows cars to cruise at about 30 km/h in the third gear without straining the engine.
===Latest developments=== KPIT continues the road tests of pilot vehicles as well as consumer trials with results so far having validated the pre-announced performance results. The team has further reduced the overall weight of the solution, improved on the durability and standardized many components across multiple vehicle platforms. Construction at the assembly and manufacturing plants continues. It is expected to be operational by March 2014.
The company will test various vehicles, including [[Automobiles|passenger cars]], with engines sizes between 800 cc and 2,500 cc.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2010/11/16/stories/2010111652720200.htm |title = KPIT plans road tests for hybrid tech soon | publisher = [[Business Line]] |date = 2010-11-15 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>
Production of limited hybrid kits is planned to start by first half of 2012.{{update inline|date=November 2017}} The commercial production would begin in 2012-13.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2010/11/16/stories/2010111652720200.htm |title = KPIT Cummins plans road tests for hybrid tech soon | publisher = [[Business Line]] |date = 2010-11-15 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>{{update inline|date=November 2017}}
==Technology==
===Revolo technology details=== The Revolo kit is similar to a [[retrofitting|retrofit]] [[compressed natural gas]] (CNG) kit which contains all required mechanical and electrical components in the package.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.wheelosphere.org/bharat-forge-india-unveil-retrofit-revolo-hybrid-kits-on-sale-in-india-in-six-months | title = Bharat Forge India unveil retrofit Revolo hybrid kits; on sale in India in six months | publisher = Wheelosphere | date = 2010-06-17 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>
The kit can be installed in both [[petrol]] and [[Diesel fuel|diesel vehicles]] within 4–6 hours by trained technicians who will be trained by a [[joint venture]] that KPIT has formed with [[Bharat Forge]].
The Revolo kit comprises a 7.5 to 10 [[horsepower]] [[electric motor]]<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/09/phev-conversions-slow-to-catch-on-in-us-but-could-be-big-elsewhere.html | title = PHEV Conversions Slow to Catch On in U.S., But Could Be Big Elsewhere | publisher = [[Edmunds.com]] | date = 2010-09-13 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref> developed and patented by KPIT, an electronic [[motor controller]], [[lead–acid battery]] pack, mechanical assembly and [[coupling]], [[proprietary software]] for control [[algorithms]] of the motor and batteries, and [[battery management system]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.thenational.ae/business/fill-the-gap-between-petrol-and-electric |title = Fill the gap between petrol and electric | publisher = [[The National (Abu Dhabi)]] |date = 2010-06-20 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>
As a parallel hybrid the motor and engine will work simultaneously and as a plug-in, the vehicle can be charged through a standard external electricity source such as a domestic [[power outlet]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nasscom.in/Nasscom/templates/NormalPage.aspx?id=59416 |title = Bharat Forge And KPIT Cummins To Form A Joint Venture - Announce ‘New Hybrid Technology Solution’ for Automobiles |publisher = [[Nasscom]] |date = 2010-06-16 |accessdate = 2010-12-09}}</ref> Unlike an electric vehicle, the vehicle will operate as a conventional fuel vehicle even if the batteries are completely drained.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nasscom.in/Nasscom/templates/NormalPage.aspx?id=59416 |title = Bharat Forge And KPIT Cummins To Form A Joint Venture - Announce ‘New Hybrid Technology Solution’ for Automobiles |publisher = [[Nasscom]] |date = 2010-06-16 |accessdate = 2010-12-09}}</ref>
===Plug-in parallel hybrid conversion kit=== The conversion kit is a lot less complex and light in weight in context of the moving engine components which effectively enhances the [[fuel efficiency]] to twice as compared to existing solutions.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.nasscom.in/Nasscom/templates/NormalPage.aspx?id=59416 |title = Bharat Forge And KPIT Cummins To Form A Joint Venture - Announce ‘New Hybrid Technology Solution’ for Automobiles |publisher = [[Nasscom]] |date = 2010-06-16 |accessdate = 2010-12-09}}</ref>
Battery specifications: The solution is battery agnostic. It can be adopted to work with various types of batteries such as [[lead–acid batteries]] or [[Lithium-ion batteries]]. The solution typically produces 60 volts from five valve-regulated, lead–acid batteries, and can be recharged from the standard Indian household current of 230 volts in 4 to 6 hours.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/09/phev-conversions-slow-to-catch-on-in-us-but-could-be-big-elsewhere.html | title = PHEV Conversions Slow to Catch On in U.S., But Could Be Big Elsewhere | publisher = [[Edmunds.com]] | date = 2010-09-13 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>
Revolo also consists of an in-built device that recognizes driving patterns and self-adjusts to provide optimum efficiency in stop-and-go traffic situations.
===Pricing=== Revolo is said to be 80 percent cheaper as compared to the [[retrofitting|after-market]] [[hybrid car]] kits available in the United States which cost around US$20,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://blogs.edmunds.com/greencaradvisor/2010/09/phev-conversions-slow-to-catch-on-in-us-but-could-be-big-elsewhere.html | title = PHEV Conversions Slow to Catch On in U.S., But Could Be Big Elsewhere | publisher = [[Edmunds.com]] | date = 2010-09-13 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref> It can be retrofitted into any vehicle at an average cost of [[Rupee|Rs.]] 100,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.livemint.com/2010/07/29211227/Cleaner-greener-cheaper.html |title = Cleaner, greener, cheaper | publisher = [[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]] |date = 2010-07-29 |accessdate = 2010-12-13}}</ref>

{{rint|cahsr|size=27}} ''(proposed Phase 2)'' }} '''San Bernardino''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|s|æ|n|_|ˌ|b|ɜːr|n|ər|ˈ|d|iː|n|oʊ}}) is a city located in the [[Inland Empire (California)|Riverside–San Bernardino metropolitan area]] (sometimes called the "Inland Empire") and that serves as the [[county seat]] of [[San Bernardino County, California]], United States. As one of the Inland Empire's anchor cities, San Bernardino spans {{convert|81|sqmi|km2}} on the floor of the [[San Bernardino Valley]] and as of 2017 has a population of 216,995.{{cite web|url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_PL_GCTPL1.ST13&prodType=table#|title=American FactFinder - Results|author=Data Access and Dissemination Systems (DADS)|publisher=}} San Bernardino is the [[List of largest California cities by population|17th-largest city]] in California and the [[List of United States cities by population|102nd-largest city]] in the United States. San Bernardino is home to numerous diplomatic missions for the Inland Empire, being one of four cities in California with numerous consulates (the other three being [[Los Angeles]], [[San Diego]], and the greater metropolitan San Francisco Bay Area including [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] and [[San Francisco]]). The governments of [[Guatemala]] and [[Mexico]] have also established their consulates in the [[Downtown San Bernardino|downtown]] area of the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.pe.com/local-news/local-news-headlines/20140307-immigration-guatemala-to-open-san-bernardino-consulate.ece|title=IMMIGRATION: Guatemala to open San Bernardino consulate|author=DAVID OLSON|date=March 7, 2014|work=Press Enterprise}} [[California State University, San Bernardino]] is located in the northwestern part of the city. The university also hosts the [[Coussoulis Arena]]. Other attractions in San Bernardino include ASU [[Fox Theatres#List of Fox Theatres|Fox Theatre]],{{cite web|title=American Sports University|url=http://www.americansportsuniversity.com/fox_theatre.php|publisher=American Sports University|accessdate=September 5, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120624162743/http://www.americansportsuniversity.com/fox_theatre.php|archivedate=June 24, 2012|df=mdy-all}} the McDonald's Museum, which is located on the original site of the world's first McDonald's, [[California Theatre (San Bernardino)|California Theatre]], the [[San Bernardino Mountains]], and [[San Manuel Amphitheater]], the largest outdoor amphitheater in the United States. In addition, the city is home to the [[Inland Empire 66ers]] baseball team; they play their home games at [[San Manuel Stadium]] in [[downtown San Bernardino]].{{cite web|url=http://www.milb.com/team2/page.jsp?ymd=20100310&content_id=8748902&vkey=team2_t401&fext=.jsp&sid=t401|title=History - Inland Empire 66ers San Manuel Stadium|work=Inland Empire 66ers}} In August 2012, San Bernardino became the largest city to file for protection under [[Chapter 9 of the U.S. Bankruptcy code]]; this has been superseded by [[Detroit]]'s filing in July 2013. San Bernardino's case was filed on August 1.{{cite web|title=City of San Bernardino, California Chapter 9 Voluntary Petition|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/AUMPLNQ/City_of_San_Bernardino_California__cacbke-12-28006__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|publisher=PacerMonitor|accessdate=22 June 2016}}{{cite web|last=Reid|first=Tim|title=San Bernardino, California, files for bankruptcy with over $1 billion in debts|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/02/us-usa-bankrupty-san-bernardino-idUSBRE87105220120802|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=September 5, 2012}} On December 2, 2015, [[2015 San Bernardino attack|a terrorist attack]] left 14 people dead and 22 seriously injured. ==History== {{Refimprove section|date=December 2009}} {{Main article|History of San Bernardino, California}} {{See also| Timeline of San Bernardino, California history}} The city of San Bernardino, California, occupies much of the [[San Bernardino Valley]], which indigenous tribespeople originally referred to as "The Valley of the Cupped Hand of God". The [[Tongva people|Tongva Indians]] also called the San Bernardino area '''Wa'aach''' in their language.[[Pamela Munro|Munro, Pamela]], et al., ''Yaara' Shiraaw'ax 'Eyooshiraaw'a. Now You're Speaking Our Language: Gabrielino/Tongva/Fernandeño''. Lulu.com: 2008. Upon seeing the immense geological arrowhead-shaped rock formation on the side of the [[San Bernardino Mountains]], they found the [[Hot spring|hot]] and [[Spring (hydrology)|cold springs]] to which the "arrowhead" seemed to point. ===19th century=== [[File:SanBernardino-1852.jpg|thumb|left|San Bernardino, 1852]] [[Politana, California|Politana]] was the first Spanish settlement in the San Bernardino Valley, named for [[Bernardino of Siena]]. Politana was established May 20, 1810, as a mission chapel and supply station by the [[Mission San Gabriel]] in the [[ranchería]] of the Guachama Indians that lived on the bluff that is now known as [[Bunker Hill (San Bernardino, California)|Bunker Hill]], near [[Lytle Creek (California)|Lytle Creek]]. Two years later the settlement was destroyed by superstitious local tribesmen, following powerful earthquakes that shook the region. Several years later, the [[Serrano people|Serrano]] and [[Cahuilla|Mountain Cahuilla]] rebuilt the Politana rancheria, and in 1819 invited the missionaries to return to the valley. They did and established the [[San Bernardino de Sena Estancia]]. Serrano and Cahuilla people inhabited Politana until long after the 1830s decree of secularization and the 1842 inclusion into the [[Rancho San Bernardino]] land grant of the [[José del Carmen Lugo]] family.[https://archive.org/details/historyofsanbern00caba Caballeria y Collell, Juan, HISTORY OF SAN BERNARDINO VALLEY, from the padres to the pioneers, 1810-1851, Times-Index Press, San Bernardino, Cal., 1902.]{{rp|37–41}} The city of San Bernardino is one of the oldest communities in the state of California, and in its present-day location, was not largely settled until 1851, after California became a state. The first [[English-American|Anglo-American]] colony was established by pioneers associated with [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] or Mormons. Following the Mormon colonists purchase of Rancho San Bernardino, and the establishment of the town of San Bernardino in 1851, San Bernardino County was formed in 1853 from parts of [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]]. Mormon colonists developed irrigated, commercial farming and lumbering, supplying agricultural produce and lumber throughout Southern California. The city was officially incorporated in 1857. Later that year, most of the colonists were recalled by [[Brigham Young]] in 1857 due to the [[Utah War]]. Once highly regarded in early California, news of the [[Mountain Meadows Massacre]] poisoned attitudes toward the Mormons. Some Mormons would stay in San Bernardino and some later returned from [[Utah]], but a real estate consortium from [[El Monte, California|El Monte]] and [[Los Angeles]] bought most of the lands of the old rancho and of the departing colonists. They sold these lands to new settlers who came to dominate the culture and politics in the county and San Bernardino became a typical American frontier town. Many of the new land owners disliked the sober Mormons, indulging in drinking at saloons now allowed in the town. Disorder, fighting and violence in the vicinity became common, reaching a climax in the 1859 [[Ainsworth - Gentry Affair]]. In 1860 a gold rush began in the mountains nearby with the discovery of [[gold]] by [[William F. Holcomb]] in [[Holcomb Valley]] early 1860. Another strike followed in the upper reach of Lytle Creek. By the 1860s, San Bernardino had also became an important trading hub in [[Southern California]]. The city already on the [[Mormon Road#Los Angeles .E2.80.93 Salt Lake Road 1855.E2.80.931905|Los Angeles – Salt Lake Road]], became the starting point for the [[Mojave Road]] from 1858 and [[Bradshaw Trail]] from 1862 to the mines along the [[Colorado River]] and within the [[Arizona Territory]] in the [[Steamboats of the Colorado River#Colorado River Gold Rush|gold rush of 1862-1864]]. [[File:SanBernardino-1865.jpg|thumb|left|San Bernardino, 1865]] Near San Bernardino is a naturally formed arrowhead-shaped rock formation on the side of a mountain. It measures 1375 feet by 449 feet. According to the Native American legend regarding the landmark arrowhead, an arrow from Heaven burned the formation onto the mountainside in order to show tribes where they could be healed. During the mid-19th century, "Dr." David Noble Smith claimed that a saint-like being appeared before him and told of a far-off land with exceptional climate and curative waters, marked by a gigantic arrowhead. Smith's search for that unique arrowhead formation began in Texas, and eventually ended at Arrowhead Springs in California in 1857. By 1889, word of the springs, along with the hotel on the site (and a belief in the effect on general health of the water from the springs) had grown considerably. Hotel guests often raved about the crystal-clear water from the cold springs, which prompted Seth Marshall to set up a bottling operation in the hotel's basement. By 1905, water from the cold springs was being shipped to Los Angeles under the newly created [[Arrowhead Water|"Arrowhead" trademark]]. Indigenous people of the San Bernardino Valley and Mountains were collectively identified by Spanish explorers in the 19th century as [[Serrano (people)|Serrano]], a term meaning highlander. Serrano living near what is now Big Bear Lake were called Yuhaviatam, or "People of the Pines". In 1866, to clear the way for settlers and gold miners, state militia conducted a 32-day campaign slaughtering men, women, and children.{{Cite web |url=http://www.sanmanuel-nsn.gov/culture_history.php.html |title=History |publisher=San Manuel Band of Mission Indians |accessdate=November 6, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823043732/http://www.sanmanuel-nsn.gov/culture_history.php.html |archivedate=August 23, 2014 |df= }} Yuhaviatam leader Santos Manuel guided his people from their ancient homeland to a village site in the San Bernardino foothills. The United States government in 1891 established it as a tribal reservation and named it after Santos Manuel. In 1867, the first Chinese immigrants arrived in San Bernardino. In 1883, [[California Southern Railroad]] established a rail link through San Bernardino between Los Angeles and the rest of the country. {{wide image|San Bernardino, California, city and village, 1909.jpg|1250px|align-cap=center|San Bernardino, California, city and village, 1909.}} ===20th century=== [[File:A view of "E" Street (or "D" Street?) and the Stewart Hotel, San Bernardino, ca.1905 (CHS-5241).jpg|thumb|A view of "E" Street and the Stewart Hotel, San Bernardino, ca.1905]] In 1905, the city of San Bernardino passed its first charter. World War II brought [[Norton Air Force Base]]. In 1940, [[Richard and Maurice McDonald]] founded [[McDonald's]], along with its innovative restaurant concept, in the city.''[[Modern Marvels]]'' "Fast Food Tech"; [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]; Viewed December 3, 2009 In 1980, the Panorama Fire destroyed 284 homes. San Bernardino won the [[All-America City]] award in 1977,{{cite web|title=Past Winners|url=https://www.nationalcivicleague.org/america-city-award/past-winners/?string=san+bernadino|website=National Civic League|accessdate=16 March 2018}} but the city subsequently went into a long decline and has only recently begun to recover from the three recessions of the late 20th/early 21st centuries. In 1994, Norton Air Force Base closed to become [[San Bernardino International Airport]]. ===21st century=== {{Expand section|City bankruptcy, 2015 shooting|date=February 2016}} In October 2003, another wildfire, the Old Fire, destroyed over 1,000 homes. In August 2012, San Bernardino filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy, with more than $1 billion in debt.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-bankrupty-san-bernardino-idUSBRE87105220120802|title=San Bernardino, California, files for bankruptcy with over $1 billion in debts|last=|first=|date=August 2, 2012|work=Reuters|access-date=June 12, 2017}} The move froze the city's payments to creditors, including its pension payments to the California Public Employees Retirement System for nearly a year. Key changes the city made during the bankruptcy process included: outsourcing its fire department to the county and re-writing the city's charter to provide a more clear chain of command. Following a judge's approval, the city emerged from bankruptcy in February 2017, making it one of the longest municipal bankruptcies in the United States.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} {{see also|2015 San Bernardino attack|North Park Elementary School shooting}} ==Geography== {{See also| Downtown San Bernardino}} [[File:Sb 2004 dt skyline 006a.jpg|thumb|right|San Bernardino with downtown in the background and the I-215 freeway in the foreground.]] According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert|59.6|sqmi|km2}}, of which {{convert|59.2|sqmi|km2}} is land and {{convert|0.4|sqmi|km2}}, or 0.74%, is water. The city lies in the San Bernardino foothills and the eastern portion of the [[San Bernardino Valley]], roughly {{convert|60|mi|km}} east of Los Angeles. Some major geographical features of the city include the [[San Bernardino Mountains]] and the [[San Bernardino National Forest]], in which the city's northernmost neighborhood, Arrowhead Springs, is located; the [[Cajon Pass]] adjacent to the northwest border; City Creek, [[Lytle Creek (California)|Lytle Creek]], [[San Timoteo Creek]], Twin Creek, Warm Creek (as modified through flood control channels) feed the [[Santa Ana River]], which forms part of the city's southern border south of [[San Bernardino International Airport]]. San Bernardino is unique among Southern Californian cities because of its wealth of water, which is mostly contained in underground aquifers. A large part of the city is over the Bunker Hill Groundwater Basin, including [[downtown San Bernardino|downtown]]. This fact accounts for a historically high water table in portions of the city, including at the former Urbita Springs, a lake which no longer exists and is now the site of the [[Inland Center]] Mall. Seccombe Lake, named after a former mayor, is a [[Water reservoir|manmade lake]] at Sierra Way and 5th Street. The San Bernardino Valley Municipal Water District ("Muni") has plans to build two more large, multi-acre lakes north and south of historic downtown in order to reduce groundwater, mitigate the risks of liquefaction in a future earthquake, and sell the valuable water to neighboring agencies.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The city has several notable hills and mountains; among them are: [[Shandin Hills|Perris Hill]] (named after Fred Perris, an early engineer, and the namesake of [[Perris, California]]); [[Shandin Hills|Kendall Hill]] (which is near California State University); and Little Mountain, which rises among [[Shandin Hills]] (generally bounded by Sierra Way, 30th Street, Kendall Drive, and [[Interstate 215 (California)|Interstate 215]]). Freeways act as significant geographical dividers for the city of San Bernardino. Interstate 215 is the major east-west divider, while [[State Route 210 (California)|State Route 210]] is the major north-south divider. [[Interstate 10 (California)|Interstate 10]] is in the southern part of the city. Other major highways include [[State Route 206 (California)|State Route 206]] (Kendall Drive and E Street); [[State Route 66 (California)|State Route 66]] (which includes the former U.S. 66); [[State Route 18 (California)|State Route 18]] (from State Route 210 north on Waterman Avenue to the northern [[City limits]] into the mountain communities), and [[California State Route 259|State Route 259]], the freeway connector between State Route 210 and I-215. ===Climate=== [[File:Sbsnow 2.jpg|thumb|January snowfall in San Bernardino with [[Shandin Hills]] in the background. near [[Verdemont, San Bernardino, California|Verdemont]] and the [[University District, San Bernardino|University District]]]] San Bernardino features a hot-summer [[Mediterranean climate]] (''Csa'' in the [[Köppen climate classification]]) with mild winters and hot, dry summers. Relative to other areas in Southern California, winters are colder, with frost and with chilly to cold morning temperatures common. The particularly arid climate during the summer prevents tropospheric clouds from forming, meaning temperatures rise to what is considered by NOAA scientists as Class Orange. Summer is also a lot warmer with the highest recorded summer temperature at 118 °F (47.8 °C) on July 6, 2018.{{cite web | url = http://www.weather.com/outlook/events/weddings/wxclimatology/monthly/graph/USCA0978 | title = Average Weather for San Bernardino, CA – Temperature and Precipitation | accessdate =October 27, 2009 | publisher = The Weather Channel }} In the winter, snow flurries occur upon occasion. San Bernardino gets an average of {{convert|16|in|mm|0}} of rain, hail, or light snow showers each year. [[Arrowhead Springs]], San Bernardino's northernmost neighborhood gets snow, heavily at times, due to its elevation of about {{convert|3000|ft|m}} above sea level. The seasonal [[Santa Ana wind]]s are felt particularly strongly in the San Bernardino area as warm and dry air is channeled through nearby [[Cajon Pass]] at times during the autumn months. This phenomenon markedly increases the wildfire danger in the foothills, canyon, and mountain communities that the cycle of cold, wet winters and dry summers helps create. According to the [[LA Times]] San Bernardino County has highest levels of [[Tropospheric ozone|ozone]] in the United States, averaging 102 parts per billion.[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-what-new-smog-rules-mean-for-california-air-pollution-20150930-story.html New attack on California's dirty air] by Tony Barboza, [[LA Times]] Oct. 226 |accessdate=July 3, 2013}} }} ===Neighborhoods and districts=== The neighborhoods of San Bernardino are not commonly named. Some reflect geographical regions that existed before annexation, and others originated with specific housing developments. [[Arrowhead Springs]] extends from the historic Arrowhead Springs Hotel and Spa in the north to I-210 in the south and from [[Shandin Hills]] in the west to east Twin Creek in the east. [[Del Rosa, San Bernardino, California|Del Rosa]] is the area generally between the foothills and Highland, Mountain and Arden Avenues. Delmann Heights is the area north of Highland Avenue, west of I-215, and east of the unincorporated area of [[Muscoy, California]] (which is within the city's sphere of influence for annexation). Some portions of Highland are within the city of San Bernardino, generally consistent with the portions of historical "West Highlands" north of Highland Avenue. The city also contains the post office for Patton, California, the area coextensive with Patton Hospital. Mountain Shadows is the development name for the area between Palm Avenue and Highland Avenue to State Route 330. The "West Side" is used generically to refer to the areas West of I-215. North Loma Linda is the area west of [[Mountain View Acres, California|Mountain View Acres]] (the border with Redlands), south of the Santa Ana River, north of the [[San Bernardino Freeway]] (I-10), and east of Tippecanoe Avenue. The area north of Northpark Boulevard from University Parkway to Electric Avenue, and the area north of 40th Street from Electric Avenue to Harrison Street is called Arrowhead Farms. The area west of University Parkway, and north of Kendall Drive to the north city area is called [[Verdemont]]. The "Bench" or "Rialto Bench" refers to the area with Rialto mailing addresses between [[Foothill Boulevard (Southern California)|Foothill Boulevard]] and Base Line Street. San Bernardino is divided into several districts. Many hotels, restaurants, and retail establishments have been built around Hospitality Lane{{cite web|url=http://www.mapquest.com/maps?address=S+E+St+%26+W+Hospitality+Ln&city=San+Bernardino&state=CA&zipcode=92408&latitude=34.06568&longitude=-117.29345&geocode=INTERSECTION |title=Hospitality Ln. & E St |publisher=Mapquest.com |accessdate=December 10, 2011}} in the southern part of the city, creating an informal [[business district]]. [[Downtown San Bernardino|Downtown]] is its own district with shopping and government buildings. In the foothills of the San Bernardino Mountains lies the [[University District, San Bernardino|University District]], which is a commercial area designed to support the California State University with shopping, dining, and high-density residential space. On the southern side of I-215 and the University District is the Cajon Pass light-industrial district where warehouses are situated to take advantage of this important connection between Southern California and the rest of the United States. On the opposite side of the city is the San Bernardino International Gateway, which encompasses the San Bernardino International Airport (SBD) and the Alliance California Logistics campus (air cargo hub). Nearby is the Burlington Northern Santa Fe rail hub. The combination of these assets (airport; rail hub; extensive freeway system; and, Cajon Pass) makes the city important in the movement of goods and people between Southern California and the rest of the United States.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The city of San Bernardino is in the process of developing a historic district around the 1918 Santa Fe Depot, which recently underwent a $15.6 million restoration.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} When completed, this area will connect to the downtown district with period street lights and street furniture, historic homes and other structures, a new museum, coffee bars and, a mercado with an architectural style in keeping with the [[Mission Revival]] station. San Bernardino has communities known for residences of millionaires and increasingly affluent sections of town: [[Del Rosa, San Bernardino, California|Del Rosa]], [[University Heights, San Bernardino, California|University Heights]] (Kendall Farms) and [[University Hills, San Bernardino, California|University Hills]], and [[Verdemont, San Bernardino, California|Verdemont]].{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} ==Demographics== {{US Census population |1880= 1673 |1890= 4012 |1900= 6150 |1910= 12779 |1920= 18721 |1930= 37481 |1940= 43646 |1950= 63058 |1960= 91922 |1970= 106869 |1980= 118794 |1990= 164164 |2000= 185401 |2010= 209924 |estyear=2017 |estimate=216995 |estref= |footnote=U.S. Decennial Census{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html|title=Census of Population and Housing|publisher=Census.gov|accessdate=June 4, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YSasqtfX?url=http://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html|archivedate=May 12, 2015|df=mdy }} }} {| class="wikitable sortable collapsible" style="font-size: 90%;" |- ! Each dot is 25 people: '''White''', '''Black''', '''Asian''', '''Hispanic''' or '''Other''' (yellow)]] ===2010=== The [[2010 United States Census]]{{cite web|url=https://www.census.gov/2010census/popmap/ipmtext.php?fl=06:0665000|title=2010 Census Interactive Population Search: CA - San Bernardino city|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau|accessdate=July 12, 2014}} reported that San Bernardino had a population of 209,924. The population density was 3,519.6 people per square mile (1,358.9/km²). The racial makeup of San Bernardino was 95,734 (45.6%) [[White (U.S. Census)|White]] (19.0% Non-Hispanic White),{{cite web|url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/06/0665000.html|title=San Bernardino (city) QuickFacts from the US Census Bureau|publisher=}} 31,582 (15.0%) [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 2,822 (1.3%) [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 8,454 (4.0%) [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 839 (0.4%) [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 59,827 (28.5%) from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 10,666 (5.1%) from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 125,994 persons (60.0%). The Census reported that 202,599 people (96.5% of the population) lived in households, 3,078 (1.5%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 4,247 (2.0%) were institutionalized. There were 59,283 households, out of which 29,675 (50.1%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 25,700 (43.4%) were [[marriage|opposite-sex married couples]] living together, 13,518 (22.8%) had a female householder with no husband present, 5,302 (8.9%) had a male householder with no wife present. There were 5,198 (8.8%) [[POSSLQ|unmarried opposite-sex partnerships]], and 488 (0.8%) [[same-sex partnerships|same-sex married couples or partnerships]]. 11,229 households (18.9%) were made up of individuals and 4,119 (6.9%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.42. There were 44,520 [[family (U.S. Census)|families]] (75.1% of all households); the average family size was 3.89. The population was spread out with 67,238 people (32.0%) under the age of 18, 26,654 people (12.7%) aged 18 to 24, 56,221 people (26.8%) aged 25 to 44, 43,277 people (20.6%) aged 45 to 64, and 16,534 people (7.9%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 28.5 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 94.0 males. There were 65,401 housing units at an average density of 1,096.5 per square mile (423.4/km²), of which 29,838 (50.3%) were owner-occupied, and 29,445 (49.7%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 3.2%; the rental vacancy rate was 9.5%. 102,650 people (48.9% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 99,949 people (47.6%) lived in rental housing units. According to the 2010 United States Census, San Bernardino had a median household income of $39,097, with 30.6% of the population living below the federal poverty line. ===Ethnic diversity=== {{more citations needed|date=April 2012}} Western, central, and parts of eastern San Bernardino are home to mixed-ethnic working class populations, of which the Latino and African-American populations comprise the vast majority of the city. Historically, many Latinos, primarily [[Mexican-American]]s and [[Mexico|Mexicans]], lived on Mount Vernon Avenue on the West Side.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jun/29/local/me-deadprez29 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Murder trial exposes gang intrigue, greed | first=Sam | last=Quinones | date=June 29, 2008|accessdate=December 2, 2016}} Since the 1960s, the Medical Center (formerly known as [[Muscoy, California|Muscoy]]) and Base Line corridors were mostly black, in particular in the east side and west side areas centering on public housing projects Waterman Gardens and the public housing on Medical Center drive. The heart of the Mexican-American community is on the West and Southside of San Bernardino, but is slowly expanding throughout the entire city.{{cite web|url=http://www.sbsun.com/elections/ci_9590759 |title=Obama inspires hope on Westside – San Bernardino County Sun |publisher=Sbsun.com |date=March 9, 2010 |accessdate=December 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217091401/http://www.sbsun.com/elections/ci_9590759 |archivedate=February 17, 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/sbcounty/stories/PE_News_Local_S_mobilize21.2f179b8.html |title=Inland get-out-the-vote effort tries personal contact |accessdate=2008-10-20 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090921175649/http://www.pe.com/localnews/sbcounty/stories/PE_News_Local_S_mobilize21.2f179b8.html |archivedate=September 21, 2009 |df=mdy }} San Bernardino's only Jewish congregation moved to Redlands in December 2009.{{cite web | last = Faturechi | first = Robert | title = San Bernardino loses its Jewish congregation | date = January 25, 2010 | accessdate =January 25, 2010 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/25/local/la-me-beliefs25-2010jan25 | work=Los Angeles Times | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}}}} Some Asian Americans live in and around the city of San Bernardino, as in a late 19th-century-era (gone) [[Chinatowns in the United States#Inland Empire|Chinatown]] and formerly [[Japanese-American]] area in Seccombe Park on the east end of downtown, and a large East-Asian community in [[North Loma Linda, California|North Loma Linda]]. Others live in nearby [[Loma Linda, California|Loma Linda]] to the south across the Santa Ana River. ==Economy== Government, retail, and [[Service industry|service industries]] dominate the economy of the city of San Bernardino. From 1998 to 2004, San Bernardino's economy grew by 26,217 jobs, a 37% increase, to 97,139. Government was both the largest and the fastest-growing employment sector, reaching close to 20,000 jobs in 2004. Other significant sectors were retail (16,000 jobs) and education (13,200 jobs).{{Cite book | last=Advisory Services Panel | title=San Bernardino, California: Crossroads of the Southwest | url=http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/civica/filebank/blobdload.asp?BlobID=4907 | publisher=[[Urban Land Institute]] | location=Washington, D.C. | date=June 24–29, 2007 | accessdate=December 26, 2007}} [[File:By Metrolink station, San Bernardino, CA.jpg|thumb|The Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway [[intermodal freight transport]] yard]] The city's location close to the [[Cajon Pass|Cajon]] and [[San Gorgonio Pass|San Gorgonio]] passes, and at the junctions of the [[I-10]], I-215, and SR-210 freeways, positions it as an intermodal logistics hub. The city hosts the [[Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway]]'s [[intermodal freight transport]] yard, the Yellow Freight Systems' [[cross-docking]] trucking center, and Pacific Motor Trucking. Large warehouses for [[Kohl's]], [[Mattel]], [[Pep Boys]], and [[Stater Bros.]] have been developed near the [[San Bernardino International Airport]]. Over the last few decades, the city's riverfront district along Hospitality Lane has drawn much of the regional economic development away from the historic [[downtown San Bernardino|downtown]] of the city so that the area now hosts a full complement of office buildings, big-box retailers, restaurants, and hotels situated around the Santa Ana River.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} The closing of [[Norton Air Force Base]] in 1994 resulted in the loss of 10,000 military and civilian jobs and sent San Bernardino's economy into a downturn that has been somewhat offset by more recent growth in the intermodal shipping industry. The jobless rate in the region rose to more than 12 percent during the years immediately after the base closing. As of 2007 households within one mile of the city core had a median income of only $20,480, less than half that of the [[Inland Empire (California)|Inland region]] as a whole.{{cite news | last=Brown | first=Josh | title=San Bernardino's base redevelopment efforts take circuitous path | url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/sbcounty/stories/PE_News_Local_D_nortonmain26.2037459.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520021635/http://www.pe.com/localnews/sbcounty/stories/PE_News_Local_D_nortonmain26.2037459.html | archivedate=May 20, 2011 | publisher=[[Press Enterprise (California)|Press Enterprise]] | date=July 25, 2007 | accessdate=December 26, 2007}} Over 15 percent of San Bernardino residents are unemployed as of 2012, and over 40 percent are on some form of public assistance.{{cite news|last=Willon|first=Phil|title=Plenty of blame on long road to San Bernardino bankruptcy|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-san-bernardino-20120713,0,3298664.story|accessdate=July 17, 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 12, 2012}} According to the US Census, 34.6 percent of residents live below the poverty level, making San Bernardino the poorest city for its population in California, and the second poorest in the US next to Detroit.{{cite news|last=Romero|first=Dennis|title=America's Second Poorest Big City is Right Here in Southern California: San Bernardino|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/10/san_bernardino_poor_poverty_so.php|accessdate=July 12, 2012|newspaper=LA Weekly|date=October 17, 2011}} {{Update|section|date=May 2015}} [[Amazon.com]] has built a new {{Convert|950,000|sqft|acre|adj=on|sigfig=2}} fulfillment warehouse on the south side of the airport, that opened in the fall of 2012, promising to create 1,000 new jobs, which will make it one of the city's largest employers. Route 66 Rendezvous |publisher=Route-66.org |accessdate=December 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20070801193319/http://www.route-66.org/ |archivedate=August 1, 2007 |df= }} a four-day celebration of America's "Mother Road" that is held in [[downtown San Bernardino]] each September; the Berdoo Bikes & Blues Rendezvous, held in the spring; the [[National Orange Show Festival]],[http://nosevents.com/NOS_fair/history.htm NOS Festival] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722154234/http://www.nosevents.com/NOS_fair/history.htm |date=July 22, 2011 }} a citrus exposition founded in 1911 and also held in the spring; and, the Western Regional [[Little League]] Championships held each August, as well as the annual anniversary of the birth of the Mother Charter of the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club, Berdoo California Chapter. ===Museums=== [[File:First McDonalds, San Bernardino, California.jpg|thumb|The site of the original [[McDonald's]] restaurant is now a [[U.S. Route 66|Route 66]] museum.]] The Robert V. Fullerton Museum of Art, located on the campus of [[California State University, San Bernardino]], contains a collection of Egyptian antiquities, ancient pottery from present-day Italy, and funerary art from ancient China. In addition to the extensive antiquities on display, the museum presents contemporary art and changing exhibitions. The Heritage House holds the collection of the [http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/about/history/historical_n_pioneer_society/default.asp San Bernardino Historic and Pioneer Society], while the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110217080149/http://www.co.san-bernardino.ca.us/museum/ San Bernardino County Museum] of regional history in [[Redlands, California|Redlands]] has exhibits relating to the city of San Bernardino as well. The San Bernardino Railroad and History Museum is located inside the historic Santa Fe Depot. A Route 66 museum is located on the historic site of the original [[McDonald's]] restaurant.{{cite web |url=http://www.route-66.com/mcdonalds/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20091012230532/http://www.route-66.com/mcdonalds/ |archive-date=October 12, 2009 |title=Welcome to the Historic Site Of The First McDonalds |dead-url=yes |accessdate=June 1, 2016}} It is at 1398 North E Street and West 14th Street. Specialty museums include the Inland Empire Military Museum,{{cite web|url=http://www.sbsun.com/ci_3652208 |title=Inland Empire Military Museum |publisher=Sbsun.com |accessdate=December 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217091511/http://www.sbsun.com/ci_3652208 |archivedate=February 17, 2012 |df= }} the American Sports Museum, and the adjacent [[WBC Legends of Boxing Museum]]. ===Performing arts=== * The 1928 [[California Theatre (San Bernardino)]], California Theater of the Performing Arts in downtown San Bernardino hosts an array of events, including concerts by the San Bernardino Symphony Orchestra, as well as touring Broadway theater productions presented by Theatrical Arts International, the Inland Empire's largest theater company.http://www.californiatheatre.net/ * [[San Manuel Amphitheater]], originally Glen Helen Pavilion at the Cajon Pass is the largest amphitheater in the United States. * [[National Orange Show Festival]] The National Orange Show Events Center contains: the Orange Pavilion; a stadium; two large clear-span exhibition halls; a clear-span geodesic dome; and several ballrooms. * [[Coussoulis Arena]] in the University District is the largest venue of its type in San Bernardino and Riverside Counties. * Sturges Center for the Fine Arts, including the 1924 Sturges Auditorium, hosts lectures, concerts, and other theater.{{cite web|url=http://www.sturgescenter.org/|title=Sturges Center for the Fine Arts|publisher=}} * Roosevelt Bowl at Perris Hill presents outdoor theater by [[Junior University]] during the summer months. * The historic 1929 Fox Theater of San Bernardino, located downtown and owned by [[American Sports University]], has recently been restored for new use. * The Lyric Symphony Orchestra in nearby [[Loma Linda, California]] presents concerts in the city and nearby communities.{{cite web|url=http://lyricsymphony.com/calendar.php|title=Lyric Symphony Orchestra|date=December 4, 2010|publisher=}} ===Resorts and tourism=== [[File:SanBernardinoValley-1907-loc.jpg|thumb|right|Arrowhead Springs Hotel, circa 1907]] San Bernardino is home to the historic Arrowhead Springs Hotel and Spa, located in the [[Arrowhead Springs, San Bernardino, California|Arrowhead Springs]] neighborhood, which encompasses {{convert|1916|acre|km2}} directly beneath the Arrowhead geological monument that presides over the San Bernardino Valley. The resort contains hot springs, in addition to mineral baths and steam caves located deep underground. Long the headquarters for Campus Crusade for Christ, the site now remains largely vacant and unused since their operations moved to Florida.{{cite web|url=http://ohp.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=21476|title=California Historical Landmarks: San Bernardino County|accessdate=August 10, 2009}} The $300 million Casino San Manuel, one of the few in southern California that does not operate as a resort hotel, is located approximately one mile from the Arrowhead Springs Hotel and Spa.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} The city is also home to the Arrowhead Country Club and Golf Course. In downtown, Clarion, adjacent to the San Bernardino Convention Center, is the largest hotel while the [[Hilton hotels|Hilton]] is the largest in the Hospitality Lane District. ===Nicknames=== San Bernardino has received many informal nicknames in its history. Of these, ''San Berdoo'', ''S.B.D.'', ''S.B.'', ''San B.'', ''Dino'', ''San Bernas'', and ''Berdoo''{{cite web|url=http://angeles.sierraclub.org/hps/signatures/26g.htm |title=Used since the 1870s |publisher=angeles.sierraclub.org |date=February 25, 2003 |accessdate=December 10, 2011}}{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,821570-1,00.html |title=Practical Presbyterian, Time Magazine, April 23, 1951 |work=Time |date=April 23, 1951 |accessdate=December 10, 2011}} are the most common but are sometimes considered derogatory or undignified. Other, more official nicknames include: ''Gate City''''See'' The San Bernardino Daily Sun, July 1918 quoted at Santa Fe Depot and the Railroads [http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/about/history/santa_fe_depot.asp] (to reflect its proximity to Los Angeles, and location at the southern and western end of the [[Cajon Pass]], leading to the High Desert and [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]); ''The Friendly City'';Interview of Edward Thomann on January 9, 2003 by Professor Joyce Hanson, for the San Bernardino Oral History Project, January 9, 2003{{cite web|url=http://www.uia.net/~sbpl/thomann.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-03 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090113182927/http://www.uia.net/~sbpl/thomann.html |archivedate=January 13, 2009 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.san-bernardino.org/about/index_about.html|title=About San Bernardino|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021023122414/http://www.san-bernardino.org/about/index_about.html|archivedate=October 23, 2002|df=mdy-all}} ''City on the Move''; and, most recently, ''The Heartbeat of [[U.S. Route 66]].''The Convention and Visitor's Bureau created this slogan, but no longer uses it ==Sports== [[File:Coussoulis Arena.JPG|thumb|left|[[California State University, San Bernardino]] (CSUSB) [[Coussoulis Arena]]]] The [[California State University, San Bernardino]] (CSUSB) [[Cal State San Bernardino Coyotes|Coyotes]] compete at the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Division II level in a variety of sports. [[San Bernardino Valley College]] competes in the [[California Community College Athletic Association|CCCAA]] and is the only school to offer football at the collegiate level in San Bernardino. CSUSB used to play their home baseball games at the downtown venue, [[Arrowhead Credit Union Park]], but now play all their home games at the uptown venue, [[Fiscalini Field]].[http://events.csusb.edu/BookingDetails.aspx?data=7cZwpiiplNtACbcICmJuEHTAwYuXXULRCdHCma2ZvkTa96xbBX1MUDNx0caPaFHJXGc5bNFB6WpiFm2%2By2ryJt57%2Bs9s3CG9tRQ%2FTgiHMRc%3D Events Calendar] San Bernardino has had other professional and semi-pro teams over the years, including the San Bernardino Jazz professional women's volleyball team, the [[San Bernardino Pride]] Senior Baseball team, and the San Bernardino Spirit California League Single A baseball team. San Bernardino also hosts the BSR West Super Late Model Series at Orange Show Speedway. The series fields many drivers, including [[NASCAR]] [[Camping World Truck Series]] regular [[Ron Hornaday, Jr.|Ron Hornaday]], who drove the No. 33 in a race on July 12, 2008. ===Inland Empire 66ers=== The city hosts the [[Inland Empire 66ers]] baseball club of the [[California League]], which since 2011 has been the [[Los Angeles Angels]] Single A affiliate. The team was the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] [[Class A (baseball)|Single A]] affiliate from 2007 to 2010. The 66ers play at [[San Manuel Stadium]] in downtown San Bernardino. ==Parks and recreation== [[File:Podupadłe imperium2.jpg|thumb|View from Perris Hill north towards Shandin Hills. The opening of the [[Cajon Pass]] is visible in the far background.]] San Bernardino offers several parks and other recreation facilities. Perris Hill Park is the largest with: Roosevelt Bowl, Fiscalini Field,{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalballparks.com/California/Fiscalini.html |title=Fiscalini Field |publisher=Digitalballparks.com |date=September 15, 2002 |accessdate=December 10, 2011}} several tennis courts, a Y.M.C.A., a senior center, a shooting range, hiking trails, and a pool. Other notable parks include: the [[Glen Helen Regional Park]], operated by the County of San Bernardino, is located in the northernmost part of the city. Blair Park is another midsized park near the [[University District, San Bernardino|University District]], it is home to a well known skate park and various hiking trails on Shandin Hills, also known as Little Mountain. ==Government== ===Local government=== According to the city's 2012 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report, the city's various funds had $313.6 million in Revenues, $298.5 million in expenditures, $1,113.3 million in total assets, $449.6 million in total liabilities, and $181.0 million in cash and investments. [[File:San Bernardino City Hall, 2009.JPG|thumb|San Bernardino City Hall building in [[downtown San Bernardino|downtown]], was designed in 1963 by [[César Pelli]]]] The city of San Bernardino is a [[charter city]], a form of government under California that allows limited home-rule, in that it can pass its own laws not in conflict with state law, such as when state law is silent, or expressly allows municipal regulations of areas of local concern. San Bernardino became a charter city in 1905, the most current charter was passed in 2004. The city of San Bernardino has a full-time, elected mayor, a [[city manager]], an elected City Attorney, [[City clerk|City Clerk]], and City Treasurer, and seven council positions elected in a ward system. The charter also created the [[San Bernardino City Unified School District]], a legally separate agency, and the Board of Water Commissioners, a semi-autonomous, but legally indistinct commission, and a Board of Library Trustees. The City Manager is responsible for all department heads, except for the fire and police chiefs. Previously, the San Bernardino Municipal Code recognized a City Administrator. When the city originally adopted a ward system, there were five wards. In the 1960s, the Council was expanded to seven wards. The boundaries are adjusted with each federal census. [[Bob Holcomb]] (1922–2010) was the longest serving Mayor of San Bernardino to date, holding the office from 1971 until 1985 and again from 1989 to 1993.{{cite news|first=James Rufus|last=Koren|title=Ex-mayor of San Bernardino dies at 88|url=http://www.sbsun.com/ci_16738877?source=most_viewed|work=[[The San Bernardino Sun]]|date=November 29, 2010|accessdate=December 11, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314032949/http://www.sbsun.com/ci_16738877?source=most_viewed|archivedate=March 14, 2012|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|first=Andrew |last=Edwards |title=Former SB mayor W.R. Criminal, family, and government lawyers are centered downtown, while local civil firms and outposts of state and national firms, corporate, and insurance defense firms, are located along Hospitality Lane. Carey Davis]] | March 3, 2014 | ''incumbent'' |} ====Bankruptcy==== On July 10, 2012, the City Council of San Bernardino decided to seek protection under [[Chapter 9, Title 11, United States Code]], making it the third California municipality to do so in less than two weeks (after [[Stockton, California|Stockton]] and the town of [[Mammoth Lakes, California|Mammoth Lakes]]), and the second-largest ever. According to state law, the city would normally have to negotiate with creditors first, but, because they declared a fiscal emergency in June, that requirement did not apply.{{cite web|title=3rd Calif. city to file for bankruptcy in 1 month|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57469953/3rd-calif-city-to-file-for-bankruptcy-in-1-month/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Church|first=Steven|title=San Bernardino Bankruptcy Judge Sets Oct. 24 Deadline|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-08-17/san-bernardino-bankruptcy-judge-sets-oct-dot-24-deadline|accessdate=August 21, 2012|newspaper=BloombergBusinessWeek|date=August 17, 2012}} The case was filed on August 1. ====Municipal code==== As a [[charter city]], San Bernardino may make and enforce its own laws as long as they are not in conflict with the laws of the State of California. These rules have been codified as the [http://sbcity.org/residents/municipal_code.asp San Bernardino Municipal Code]. Violations of the code, punishable as a [[misdemeanor]] or [[infraction]] (or both) are prosecuted by the City Attorney's Office in the [http://www.sb-court.org/ San Bernardino County Superior Court]. The city also has two administrative processes for violations of the code, as well as other adopted codes, like the [[California Building Standards Code#Parts|California Building Code]] and the [[California Building Standards Code#Parts|California Fire Code]]. One process is an administrative citation system, similar to a [[Parking violation|parking ticket]], with a pay or contest procedure. The other is an [[Hearing (law)|administrative hearing]] process, generally used by the Code Enforcement Department for prosecuting multiple code violations. ====City of San Bernardino Economic Development Agency==== The Redevelopment Agency of the City of San Bernardino, also known as the "Economic Development Agency of the City of San Bernardino," is a separate legal entity, though the City Council of the city of San Bernardino sits as the Agency Board, and the mayor is its executive.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} ====Downtown San Bernardino revitalization efforts==== In June 2009, the city's Economic Development Agency, presented the San Bernardino City Council with the Downtown Core Vision / Action Plan{{cite web |author=City of San Bernardino EDA, Pirih Productions, and Brostrom Software Solutions |url=http://www.sbrda.org/corevision.htm |title=Downtown Core Vision |publisher=Sbrda.org |accessdate=December 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009125146/http://www.sbrda.org/corevision.htm |archive-date=October 9, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}– a guide for revitalizing Downtown San Bernardino for the next 10 years. The plan, which the city council approved to support, is the culmination of a year of research, community participation, and planning led by the city's EDA and the urban planning firm EDAW which has worked on master planning across the globe for downtown areas that include Milan, Italy; London, England; New York, New York; and Denver, Colorado, to name a few. A driving force in the initial phase of the revitalization efforts is the development of an arts and culture district in the heart of Downtown San Bernardino.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}} This effort is being anchored by the historic and iconic California Theatre, which has been in continuous operation since first opening its doors in 1928. California-based Maya Cinemas, which is adjacent to California Theatre, is in the process of renovating the former CinemaStar movie theatre. These two entertainment facilities are the foundation of what will become a vibrant center for the arts and culture. ===Joint-power authorities=== San Bernardino shares certain powers with other agencies to form legally separate entities known as joint-power authorities under California law. These include [[Omnitrans]], which provides transportation throughout the east and west valleys of San Bernardino County, SANBAG, which coordinates transportation projects throughout the county, and the Inland Valley Development Agency, which is responsible for redevelopment of the areas around the [[San Bernardino International Airport]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} ===County seat=== [[File:San Bernardino County Court House.JPG|right|thumb|San Bernardino County Court House, built in 1926.]] San Bernardino is the [[county seat]] of [[San Bernardino County]], the largest formal county in the contiguous United States by area, but smaller than the informally organized county equivalent [[Yukon-Koyukuk Census Area, Alaska]] and the formal county equivalent [[North Slope Borough, Alaska]], as well as 4 other formal county equivalents and 5 other informally organized county equivalents in [[Alaska]]. Various [[State court (United States)|state courts]], (for civil, criminal and juvenile trials) operate under the auspices of the [[Superior court|Superior Court]], San Bernardino District (formerly Central Division prior to the unification of the Superior and Municipal Courts in 1998). Currently, the [[Superior Court of California]] county courthouse is located at 351 North Arrowhead Avenue. It consists of a four-story building of steel and concrete construction built in 1927. A six-story addition was added in the 1950s. Currently, the 1926 structure is being retrofitted. A new courthouse, located at 247 West Third Street, opened in 2014, which houses civil courts. Juvenile Court and Juvenile Hall are located in a county enclave adjacent to the city on Gilbert Street, near the site of the former County Hospital. The County's [[District attorney|District Attorney]] and the Public Defender both have their main offices on Mountain View Avenue, directly east of the Courthouse. The [[California Court of Appeal]] Fourth District, Division Two used to be located in San Bernardino, but moved to Riverside in the 1990s. Federal cases (including Bankruptcy) are also heard in Riverside courthouses. [[File:San Bernardino County Arrowhead Plaza.jpg|right|thumb|San Bernardino County Government Center, 385 North Arrowhead Avenue in [[downtown San Bernardino]]]] ===Public safety=== The 1905 Charter created the San Bernardino Police Department and chief of police; before 1905, there was a position of city marshal. The current charter places the chief of police under the direction of the mayor. The San Bernardino City Fire Department was founded in 1878 and dissolved on July 1, 2016 to be taken over by the San Bernardino County Fire District.{{cite web|url=http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/depts/fire/stations.asp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305184545/http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/depts/fire/stations.asp |archivedate=March 5, 2007 |title=San Bernardino City Fire Department. ''Stations'' |publisher=Ci.san-bernardino.ca.us |accessdate=December 10, 2011}} Charter Section 186 requires that the monthly salaries of police and fire local safety members be the average of like positions at ten comparable cities in California.City of San Bernardino, Charter section 186, San Bernardino Municipal Code section 1.28.020 Thus, if the average goes up in other cities, the compensation of the local safety employees automatically rises. Over 90 percent of local police officers do not live within the city limits.{{cite web|url=http://www.blackvoicenews.com/commentary/hardy-l-brown/40592-editorials-by-hardy-brown.html |title=Brinker, Derry, Kelley & McCammack 'Wrapped Up, Tied Up, Tangled Up' . . . Ethics Gone |author=Brown, Hardy|date=March 15, 2007|accessdate=2012-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521115313/http://www.blackvoicenews.com/commentary/hardy-l-brown/40592-editorials-by-hardy-brown.html |archivedate=May 21, 2014 |work =San Bernardino Black Voice News }} Recent police efforts include joint patrols with the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department and the [[California Highway Patrol]]. As of November 2006,{{cite web|url=http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/civica/filebank/blobdload.asp?BlobID=3580 |title=November 2006 Part 1 Crime in San Bernardino |accessdate=December 10, 2011}} Part 1 Crime (Murders, Rape, Robbery, Assault, Burglary and Theft) was down 14.07 percent from 2005. Stricter enforcement caused a rise in both juvenile and adult arrests.{{cite web|url=http://www.ci.san-bernardino.ca.us/civica/filebank/blobdload.asp?BlobID=3530 |title=Juvenile and adult arrests in San Bernardino |accessdate=December 10, 2011}} San Bernardino has long battled high crime rates. According to statistics published by [[Morgan Quitno]], San Bernardino was the 16th most dangerous US city in 2003,{{cite web|url=http://www.morganquitno.com/cit05pop.htm |title=Morgan Quitno. 2005 city crime statistics |publisher=Morganquitno.com |accessdate=December 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225033434/http://www.morganquitno.com/cit05pop.htm |archivedate=December 25, 2011 |df= }} 18th in 2004{{cite web|url=http://www.comunidadesegura.org/?q=en/node/30265 |title=Comunidad Segura. San Bernardino's murder rate was 29 per 100,000 in 2005, the 13th highest murder rate in the country and the third highest in the state of California after [[Compton, California|Compton]] and [[Richmond, California|Richmond]].{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0934323.html |title=Infoplease.
